messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] speaking of publishing...
messages.msgSnippet: ... There is a reason that text could be a problem. In general, you re looking at 180 dpi for the recommended resolution of photographs and pictures. You could
messages.messageBody:
<rkg@...> writes:

> Hey guys, In case anybody is interested, there are several companies
> that will do short run books for what seem to be pretty reasonable
> prices - check out this week's business week - the three listed are
> snapfish.com, imagestation.com, and MyPublisher.com - they talked
> about using them for photos mostly, but I can't see any reason why you
> couldn't throw jpegs with typing in 'em as well...

There is a reason that text could be a problem.

In general, you're looking at 180 dpi for the recommended resolution of
photographs and pictures. You could go as low as 150dpi in some cases,
but everything over 180dpi is overkill.

For text, the line is drawn around 400dpi.

If these guys are stuck on photos, you may have a 180dpi resolution
hardcoded everywhere... which means your text will look bad.

Still worthwhile to look into, but this should be kept in mind.

- darcy

messages.subject: speaking of publishing...
messages.msgSnippet: Hey guys, In case anybody is interested, there are several companies that will do short run books for what seem to be pretty reasonable prices - check out this
messages.messageBody:
Hey guys,

In case anybody is interested, there are several companies that will do
short run books for
what seem to be pretty reasonable prices - check out this week's
business week - the three
listed are snapfish.com, imagestation.com, and MyPublisher.com - they
talked about using them
for photos mostly, but I can't see any reason why you couldn't throw
jpegs with typing in 'em
as well...

Immortalize your collection now :-)

rkg
(Richard George)
